qas.question: What work by Avicenna is thought to be a fake?

answers.text: Liber Aboali Abincine de Anima in arte Alchemiae

qas.question: What is another work of Avicenna that is said to not be his creation?
What is definitely seen as being written by Avicenna?
What did Ibn Sina classify into stones?

plausible_answers.text: Liber Aboali Abincine de Anima in arte Alchemiae

qas.question: What work by Avicenna is thought to be a real?
What is another work of Avicenna that is said to be his creation?
What is definitely seen as being read by Avicenna?
What didn't Ibn Sina classify into stones?

context: <a0_0><b5_0>Liber Aboali Abincine de Anima in arte Alchemiae<b5_0/><a0_0/> was the most influential, having influenced later medieval chemists and alchemists such as Vincent of Beauvais. However Anawati argues (following Ruska) that the de Anima is a fake by a Spanish author. Similarly <a1_0><b6_0>the Declaratio<b6_0/><a1_0/> is believed not to be actually by Avicenna. The third work (<a2_0><b7_0>The Book of Minerals<b7_0/><a2_0/>) is agreed to be Avicenna's writing, adapted from the Kitab al-Shifa (<a3_0><b8_0>Book of the Remedy<b8_0/><a3_0/>). Ibn Sina classified <a4_0><b9_0>minerals<b9_0/><a4_0/> into stones, fusible substances, sulfurs, and salts, building on the ideas of Aristotle and Jabir. The epistola de Re recta is somewhat less sceptical of alchemy; Anawati argues that it is by Avicenna, but written earlier in his career when he had not yet firmly decided that transmutation was impossible.
